newsitem.title: SWEDEN: Blair, Jospin stress difficulties facing EMU.
newsitem.headline: Blair, Jospin stress difficulties facing EMU.

text.p: Prime ministers Tony Blair of Britain and Lionel Jospin of France met briefly on Thursday and agreed that the European Union's planned single currency faces difficulties, a British official said.

The two leaders spoke -- mixing English and French -- for 10 minutes on the fringes of the annual congress of Europe's social democratic parties which opened in the southern Swedish city of Malmo on Thursday.
"They both spoke of the difficulties the single currency would face," the British official said.

He said Jospin, whose Socialist party swept to power last Sunday calling for a change of direction in Europe, was in particular "very clear" about problems facing the single currency, scheduled to be introduced in 1999.

Monetary union has not won popular favour within the EU because countries seeking to qualify for it have sought to slash social spending and fiscal support of their economies, eroding welfare benefits and aggravating unemployment.

The two leaders also broached the inter-governmental conference to overhaul the European Union's institutions, which is due to conclude at a summit in Amsterdam on June 16-17, as well as Blair's ideas for promoting labour market flexibility in Europe.
Jospin and Blair were the last to arrive for a dinner at Malmo town hall, where a crowd of noisy extreme left-wingers made clear their disapproval of the British leader's moderate policies.
"Blair doesn't care, Liverpool dockers need support," they shouted, alluding to a long-running strike in Britain.
Jospin skipped the dinner, popping into the town hall only to give his apologies to his fellow Socialist leaders.
